* For all <math>n \in \mathbb{N},</math> let <math>t_{n}</math> be the number of <math>\{a, b, c\}</math>-strings of length <math>n</math>, (which we will denote as <math>\left\{ a, b, c \right\}^{n}</math>) not having <math>a b c</math> as a substring. 
** For example, if <math>n=8</math>, <math>cbacabac</math> is allowed, but not <math>ababcaab</math>. 
Find a recurrence relation for <math>t_{n}</math> and use it to compute <math>t_{8}</math>.

== Solution ==
* Let <math>\mathcal{S}_{n} = \left\{ x : x \in \left\{ a, b, c \right\}^{n}, abc \not\sqsubseteq x \right\}</math> (Namely, the set of <math>\{a, b, c\}</math> -strings of length <math>n</math> not having <math>a b c</math> as a substring).
* In the following calculations we will require that <math>n \ge 3</math>, so by hand we obtain <math>t_{0}=1</math> for <math>\epsilon</math> <math>t_{1}=3</math>, <math>t_{2}=3^{2}=9</math> 

* If <math>s</math>'s last character is <math>a</math> or <math>b</math>, they could have been generated by <math>\mathcal{S}_{n-1}</math> and then appending an <math>a</math> or <math>b</math> to the end so there would be <math>2  \cdot \mathcal{S}_{n-1}</math> such strings
* If <math>s</math>'s last character is <math>c</math>, then  the two characters that appear before it must not be <math>ab</math>, so let's count how many valid strings of <math>\mathcal{S}_{n-1}</math> do not end in <math>ab</math>. 
** The number of strings that do end in <math>ab</math> can be generated by <math>\mathcal{S}_{n-3}</math> and then adding <math>ab</math> to the end, as appending <math>ab</math> to the end could never generate the substring <math>abc</math>. 
* So the number of valid strings ending in <math>c</math> is <math>\mathcal{S}_{n-1}- \mathcal{S}_{n-3}</math>, in total we have that 
<math display="block">  t_{n}=2  \cdot t_{n-1} + \left( t_{n - 1} - t_{n-3}\right)  = 3 \cdot t_{n-1} - t_{n-3}</math>
